channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Formula for Power in Modi’s India: Cash, Detentions and Luxe Resorts
item.description: With a tactic known as “resort politics,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party has been accused of using brute force to take over Indian state governments.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Nitin Deshmukh, a lawmaker in the state of Maharashtra, India, said he was detained, including at a government hospital, and pressured to join rebel politicians in an uprising.

item.title: A Lesson for America? Reversing Populist Policies Is Tough, Poland Finds.
item.description: The country’s new leaders are trying to undo changes, like abortion restrictions and politicized courts, made by their hard-right predecessors. It “takes longer than you expect,” one minister said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Anna Liminowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court in Warsaw. The previous government, under the Law and Justice party, stacked Polish courts with right-wing loyalists.

item.title: 55 Days Into Hunger Strike, Activist’s Mother Says She ‘Won’t Back Down’
item.description: Laila Soueif, the British-born mother of the Egyptian political prisoner Alaa Abd El Fattah, is demanding the U.K. do more to secure his release.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Laila Soueif, the mother of the Egyptian political prisoner Alaa Abd El Fattah in 2022. She stopped eating on Sept. 29, after it became clear that her son would not be released after serving a five-year sentence.

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Right Wing Movement Faces Backlash After Coup Accusations
item.description: Accusations that former far-right President Jair Bolsonaro plotted a coup arose after a former top aide of his was implicated in a plan to kill the current president.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Brazilian police are seeking charges against Jair Bolsonaro, the former far-right president, accusing him of taking part in a coup plot.

item.title: Iran Declares It Is Doing More Nuclear Enrichment After I.A.E.A. Rebuke
item.description: With thousands of advanced centrifuges on standby, Tehran says it is now spinning more, which could increase its stockpile of near-bomb-grade atomic fuel.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: A satellite view of Iran’s Fordo fuel enrichment plant inside a mountain northeast of the city of Qum.

item.title: How Can the I.C.C. Prosecute Leaders of Israel, Which Is Not a Member?
item.description: The jurisdiction of the court in The Hague can extend beyond member states.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson and Marlise Simons
item.media:credit: Laurens Van Putten/Anp, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague in the Netherlands.

item.title: Terms of Proposed Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Begin to Take Shape, Officials Say
item.description: Key details still needed to be worked out between Israel and Hezbollah, and disagreements could scuttle or delay any deal, the officials said. But some cited reasons for cautious optimism.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Isabel Kershner and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike in Mar Elias, central Beirut, Lebanon, on November 18.

item.title: Israel Rallies Around Netanyahu Over I.C.C. Warrant, for Now
item.description: An I.C.C. arrest warrant for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the war in Gaza spurred outrage across Israel’s political spectrum. But in the long term, it’s not a good look for a prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Next month, Mr. Netanyahu is expected to take the stand in his own corruption trial. He has been charged with bribery, fraud and breach of trust in three separate but interrelated cases.

item.title: Israel Strikes Across Lebanon After Ordering Evacuations of Southern Towns
item.description: The wide-scale bombardment continued a day after a U.S. envoy held talks with Israeli officials on a possible cease-fire with Hezbollah militants.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Liam Stack

item.title: As Ukraine Fires U.S. Missiles, Putin Sends a Chilling Message
item.description: The Russian leader ominously declares that America risks nuclear war as it expands its aid.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing at advancing Russian troops in the Pokrovsk area in eastern Ukraine last week.

item.title: Orban Invites Netanyahu to Hungary, Flouting I.C.C. Arrest Warrant
item.description: Hungary, unlike the United States, is a signatory to the court, which accused the Israeli leader of war crimes in Gaza. Responses to the warrant from other European countries were varied.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with his Hungarian counterpart, Viktor Orban, in Budapest in 2017.

item.title: Pat King Found Guilty for Role in ‘Freedom Convoy’
item.description: The verdict was in the high-profile case of Pat King, a man accused of helping provoke disruptions during the so-called trucker convoy, which paralyzed Canada’s capital during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pat King, a prominent figure in Canada’s protests against Covid restrictions in 2022, surrounded by supporters on Friday while leaving court in Ottawa, Ontario.

item.title: South Africa’s A.N.C. Rejects Jacob Zuma’s Appeal Against His Expulsion
item.description: The country’s governing party had severed ties with the former president in July after he campaigned for an opposition party in the last general election.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Former South African President Jacob Zuma in court in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, in August.

item.title: Ukraine Cancels Parliament Session, Citing a Warning Over a Missile Attack
item.description: This is the first time Parliament has canceled a session since Russia invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s Parliament canceled a session on Friday over a warning that Russia could target the building.

item.title: Powerful Israeli Airstrike Hits Central Beirut
item.description: The attack was the third strike in the Lebanese capital this week, part of a wave of amped-up Israeli military activity across the country.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli strike in Beirut’s Basta neighborhood on Saturday.

item.title: Conor McGregor, U.F.C. Fighter, Is Held Liable for Sexual Assault in Ireland
item.description: The mixed martial arts fighter known as “Notorious” was ordered to pay the equivalent of about $260,000 to a woman who said he raped her in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The mixed martial arts fighter Conor McGregor outside the High Court in Dublin on Friday.

item.title: At COP29 Politicians Are Talking About Climate Change. Here’s What’s Happening.
item.description: Every month so far has seen floods, fires, smashed heat records or some combination of extreme weather. Little time remains for leaders to agree on what to do about it.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: R. Satish Babu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Fires and punishing heat in a suburb of Chennai, India, in May.

item.title: Guard at U.S. Embassy in Norway Accused of Spying for Russia and Iran
item.description: The Norwegian man was arrested this week in Oslo and ordered jailed pending further investigation in what the authorities called a ‘very serious case.’
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oslo at sunset. Authorities in Norway have arrested a man who worked as a security guard at the United States embassy there.

item.title: Merkel Memoir Recalls What It Was Like Dealing With Trump and Putin
item.description: The new book by former Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany also aims to justify decisions she made that are still affecting her country and the rest of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: An awkward silence between Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office in 2017, shortly after his inauguration.

item.title: Russia Supplies Antiaircraft Missiles, to North Korea, the South Says
item.description: Pyongyang has long coveted an advanced air-defense system to guard against missiles and war planes from the United States and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un of North Korea with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a broadcast shown in Seoul this month.

item.title: At COP29, ‘Sewage Beer’ Is Just Fine
item.description: The hoppy pilsner from Singapore, where freshwater is scarce, is part of an effort to promote recycling solutions.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The Singaporean pavilion this week at COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s new choice for attorney general.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President-elect Donald Trump announced that he would nominate Pam Bondi to be attorney general after Matt Gaetz, his first choice, withdrew from consideration.

item.title: The UK Faces a Dilemma: Cozy Up to Trump or Reconnect With Europe?
item.description: A Trump administration may force Prime Minister Keir Starmer to choose between his country’s most powerful ally and its biggest trading partner.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain joined President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris last week to celebrate Armistice Day.

item.title: China’s Hacking Reached Deep Into U.S. Telecoms
item.description: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said hackers listened to phone calls and read texts by exploiting aging equipment and seams in the networks that connect systems.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The barn door is still wide open, or mostly open,” Senator Mark Warner of Virginia, a former telecommunications executive, said in an interview.

item.title: West Bank Settlement Supporters Have Big Hopes for Trump’s Presidency
item.description: As Donald J. Trump nominates staunch supporters of Israel to key positions, advocacy groups are taking aim at the departing administration's policies.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction in an Israeli settlement in the West Bank in December.

item.title: 6 Airports in Northern Haiti Are Reopened to U.S. Flights
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday it was allowing air traffic to resume at half a dozen airports in Haiti, but the country’s main flight hub in the capital would remain off limits.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Toussaint Louverture International Airport in Port-au-Prince has been closed to U.S. airlines since Nov. 12, but six airports in northern Haiti were reopened to American flights on Thursday.

item.title: I.C.C. Issues Arrest Warrants for Netanyahu and Gallant Over Gaza War
item.description: The court accused Benjamin Netanyahu and his former defense minister of having “intentionally and knowingly deprived” Gaza’s population of food, water, fuel and medicine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Aaron Boxerman, Steven Erlanger and Thomas Fuller
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yoav Gallant attending a military ceremony last month. Mr. Netanyahu removed Mr. Gallant as defense minister earlier this month.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Gaetz Ends Bid for Attorney General
item.description: Plus, bathing in crude oil.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Gaetz, left, on Capitol Hill on Wednesday.

item.title: U.N. Watchdog Censures Iran Over Nuclear Program Secrecy
item.description: The action could lead to sanctions against Tehran, which has barred international monitoring of its accelerated uranium enrichment efforts.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The headquarters of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, Austria, on Thursday.

item.title: Mali’s Junta Replaces Civilian Prime Minister With One of Its Own
item.description: The prime minister had been fired for criticizing the country’s junta.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Elian Peltier and Saikou Jammeh
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdoulaye Maiga delivering remarks at the 79th session of the United Nations General Assembly in September. He was appointed as the new prime minister of Mali on Thursday after his predecessor made comments criticizing the junta.

item.title: Netanyahu Aide Is Indicted Over Leaked Document on Hamas
item.description: One of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s advisers is accused of leaking a top-secret document to a German tabloid in an attempt to influence public sentiment on hostage negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has accused Israeli prosecutors of aggressively cracking down on his aide while ignoring his critics’ leaks to the news media.

item.title: Man Who Faked Kayaking Death Says in Video He’s ‘Safe’
item.description: Ryan Borgwardt, who is believed to be in Eastern Europe and has been communicating with the authorities, has not committed to returning to the U.S., officials said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Green Lake County Sheriff's Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sheriff Mark A. Podoll of Green Lake County, Wis., played a video at a news conference on Thursday in which the man accused of faking his own death says that he is “safe, secure, no problem.”

item.title: Brazilian Police Accuse Bolsonaro of Plotting a Coup
item.description: Former President Jair Bolsonaro could face criminal charges over accusations that he was involved in plans to stage a coup after losing the 2022 elections.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s former right-wing president, at a rally in February. The authorities say he encouraged supporters to storm the country’s capital in early 2023.

item.title: Trump’s Vow to End the War Could Leave Ukraine With Few Options
item.description: One question is whether the new administration and Europe will provide security guarantees to prevent Russia from taking more territory.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing at Russian troops in the Donbas region in eastern Ukraine last month. The election of Donald J. Trump as Ukraine suffers losses on the battlefield means less room for Ukraine to maneuver.

item.title: Why Some Countries, Including the U.S., Won’t Join the I.C.C.
item.description: More than 120 countries are members of the court. The United States, China, India, Russia and Israel are not.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague, Netherlands, in 2022.

item.title: Captain Tom’s Daughter Profited From the Charity in His Name
item.description: The family of Captain Tom Moore, who raised $50 million for Britain’s health service during the pandemic, has been criticized for ‘serious and repeated’ misconduct by an official inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Captain Tom Moore raised nearly 40 million pounds, or $50.5 million, for the National Health Service during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Netanyahu, Wanted by a Landmark Warrant, Now Faces a Smaller World
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has allies among the members of the International Criminal Court. But he will have to plan his travel more carefully than before.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Steven Erlanger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after a speech to the U.N. General Assembly in September in New York City.

item.title: Spain Looks to Grant Residency to Nearly 1 Million Migrants
item.description: The government said new rules could give legal status — and work permits — to about 300,000 people a year over the next three years to address gaps in the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants having breakfast on the roof of an abandoned factory in Barcelona in 2018. People who have been living in Spain for at least two years are eligible to apply for legal status.

item.title: U.S. Defense Firms Are Warned About Russia’s Sabotage Campaign
item.description: A new warning urges defense companies to increase security and to be on the lookout for surveillance and signs of trespassing.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. Russia’s campaign increases the risk to American companies overseas, U.S. officials said.

item.title: Why the ICC Issued Arrest Warrants for Israeli and Hamas Leaders
item.description: The International Criminal Court said there were grounds to hold two Israeli leaders responsible for the crisis in Gaza, and a Hamas military leader for crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The exterior of the International Criminal Court, in The Hague, Netherlands, in September.

item.title: At Least 38 Killed as Gunmen Ambush Shiite Convoys in Pakistan
item.description: The attack was one of the deadliest in months of violence between Sunnis and Shiites in the Kurram region.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Local residents and volunteers gathering for the arrival of victims at a hospital in Parachinar, in Pakistan’s Kurram district, on Thursday.

item.title: Who Has the ICC Charged With War Crimes?
item.description: The short list includes Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the deposed president of Sudan, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, with Maria Lvova-Belova, also subject to an I.C.C. arrest warrant, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: John Prescott, Former UK Deputy Prime Minister, Dies at 86
item.description: He was a cruise ship waiter before rising in the trade union movement and becoming one of the country’s best-known Labour politicians under Tony Blair.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Michael Crabtree/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: John Prescott in London in 1998.

item.title: Putin Escalates Threats to the West With New Ballistic Missile Launch
item.description: The intermediate-range missile did not carry nuclear weapons, but it is part of a strategic arsenal that is capable of delivering them.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Lara Jakes, Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in eastern Ukraine last week.

item.title: ICC Had Sought Warrants for 3 Hamas Leaders. At Least 2 Are Now Dead.
item.description: Karim Khan had asked the court to issue warrants for Hamas’s top leader in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar; its political leader, Ismail Haniyeh; and its military chief, Muhammad Deif.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: The court’s chief prosecutor initially sought arrest warrants for three Hamas leaders. From left to right: Ismail Haniyeh, Muhammad Deif and Yahya Sinwar.

item.title: Deaths of at Least 5 Tourists in Laos Raise Alarm About Tainted Drinks
item.description: Travelers from the United States, Britain, Australia and Denmark have died in the Southeast Asian nation in recent days. Officials warned of poisoning caused by alcoholic drinks containing methanol.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: At a bar in Vang Vieng, Laos, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Strikes Near Beirut as U.S. Envoy Pushes for a Cease-Fire in Lebanon
item.description: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, was in Israel and planned to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, seeking a truce in the country’s war with the militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising after an Israeli airstrike on the Dahiya, south of Beirut, Lebanon, on Thursday.

item.title: Should Olaf Scholz Step Aside in the New Race for German Chancellor?
item.description: Increasing numbers in his own center-left party say he should, arguing for a more charismatic leader who might better their electoral chances.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, left, with Boris Pistorius, the country’s defense minister, during a session of Parliament earlier this month in Berlin.

item.title: Bathing in Oil at a Climate Summit? It Leaves a Stain.
item.description: In Azerbaijan, site of the COP29 climate talks and a petrostate, people aren’t only proud of their oil. They swear by its health benefits and visit resorts to soak in it.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: People from across the former Soviet Union flock to the health resorts in Naftalan, Azerbaijan, to bathe in the area’s oil.

item.title: How Forced Labor and Hysterectomies Are Darkly Linked in India
item.description: Our correspondent explains how an exploitative labor system has produced a system of brutality in the country’s sugar fields.
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pushpa Pawar, 31, standing with relatives in the village of Kolgaon, India. Ms. Pawar’s husband, Prahlad Pawar, a cane cutter, said that the couple and their children had been detained by a contractor and forced to work as servants.

item.title: Why Mexico Isn’t Panicking About Another Trump Presidency
item.description: Mexico is banking on its ability to negotiate with a deal maker like Donald J. Trump, and many officials say the country is better prepared and has more leverage than it did during his first term.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump speaks during a meeting of the House of Representatives G.O.P. Conference at the Hyatt Regency in Washington, on Nov. 13.

item.title: Canada Prepares for Immigration Surge After Trump Vows Mass Deportation
item.description: The Canadian authorities are preparing for a possible spike in undocumented migrants, just as Trump appointees complain about too many people arriving from Canada.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants who had crossed the border from Canada, many of them from India, talking to taxi drivers in Plattsburgh, N.Y., who were offering rides to New York City.

item.title: Abused Workers in India’s Sugar Industry Face Worse Fates if They Quit
item.description: Why would anyone stay in a job where abuse is rampant and women are coerced into hysterectomies? Because the cost of escaping India’s cane fields is often even higher.
item.dc:creator: Qadri Inzamam, Megha Rajagopalan and Saumya Khandelwal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prahlad Pawar, 34, right, with his wife, Pushpa Pawar, 31, in Kolgaon, western India. The Pawars say their employer made them work as his personal servants in the off-season. They eventually escaped, hiking for days back to their village.

item.title: COP29 Climate Talks in Baku, Azerbaijan, Are Teetering
item.description: Western countries are confronting demands for trillions of dollars to fight climate change and to cope with its worsening effects.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The Chinese delegation pavilion in Baku, Azerbaijan. Newly industrialized countries like China and India are part of an effort to secure trillions in climate financing.

item.title: Russia Gifts Bears and a Lion to North Korea
item.description: Vladimir Putin also presented a lion to Pyongyang Zoo, one of the more than 70 animals he sent as an emblem of the deepening friendship between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A lion at the Pyongyang Zoo in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Wednesday, after being transferred from the Moscow Zoo, in a handout photo from Russia’s natural resources ministry.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Gaetz appeared with Senator JD Vance in Washington.

item.title: Israel and Iran Seemed on the Brink of a Bigger War. What’s Holding Them Back?
item.description: So far, direct attacks between the two adversaries have been precise and calculated. Whether that lasts is another question.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: People stand near the remains of a missile near the Dead Sea, in Israel, in October.

item.title: Accusations of “Race-Shifting” Prompt Canadian Cabinet Minister to Resign
item.description: Randy Boissonnault, who resigned as employment minister, had long described himself as the great-grandson of a Cree woman, but now acknowledges he was wrong about his family’s ancestry.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Randy Boissonnault stepped down as Canada’s employment minister on Wednesday, dealing another blow to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

item.title: Senate Rejects Bernie Sanders’s Bills to Block Weapons Transfers to Israel
item.description: The legislation failed resoundingly but highlighted a growing Democratic divide over whether the United States should withhold some weapons to register its disapproval of Israel’s war tactics.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: People running toward humanitarian aid packages dropped over the northern Gaza Strip in April.
